newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK Telecom seen benefiting as China stake rises.
newsitem.headline: HK Telecom seen benefiting as China stake rises.

text.p: The future of Hong Kong Telecommunications looks brighter now that its parent Cable and Wireless Plc has sold a stake to state-owned China Telecom, analysts in Hong Kong said on Saturday.
"The shareholding changes will provide an opportunity for Hongkong Telecom to get exposure to the fast-growing telecom industry in China," said Ben Kwong, director of research at Dharmala Securities.

Britain's Cable & Wireless (C&W) on Friday ended months of speculation by announcing that it would sell to China Telecom a 5.5 percent, or US$1.185 billion, stake in HK Telecom -- its most lucrative asset -- for HK$14.25 per share.
Before the sale, C&W held 59.2 percent of HK Telecom.

"We expect this partnership to deepen and develop further as new opportunities for investment in China are identified and quantified," C&W chief executive Richard Brown said in a statement released on Friday.
Hong Kong analysts said the deal paved the way for HK Telecom's participation in China's developing telecommunications sector, helping it diversify away from a saturated Hong Kong market.
"Hong Kong Telecom's main business is not exciting at all. What would make it more exciting is its participation in the China market," said Stanley Ng, research manager at Mansion House Securities.
HK Telecom has lagged the local stock market over the past two years because of sluggish growth prospects for fixed-line services and increased competition in the cellular phone market.
But Ng said it is too early to tell how much business HK Telecom can hope to generate in China.
"We can expect China to open up the telecom market to outsiders and that it will allow HK Telecom to participate. But at what pace and how much will Telecom get?" said Ng.
China Telecom is controlled by Telpo Communications Development Ltd, a holding company of China's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications (MPT).
In May, China Everbright, which is controlled by China's State Council, said it would buy CITIC Pacific Ltd's 7.74 percent stake in HK Telecom for HK$12.60 per share.
China Everbright is one of 16 equal holders of China United Telecommunications Corp, China's second-biggest telecommunications vendor.
Under terms of the deal with China Telecom, C&W can transfer shares to the Chinese company until both become equal partners.
Linus Cheung, HK Telecom chief executive, said on Friday that neither Telecom nor C&W had been under any political pressure from China to make a deal.

Stephen Ip, Hong Kong's Secretary for Economic Services, told a Hong Kong cable television station on Saturday that the deal did not imply Chinese interference in Hong Kong's telecommunications sector.
"It is very clear that in Hong Kong, China Telecom's business will be monitored under Hong Kong law," said Ip.
He also said C&W would need approval from the Hong Kong government to cut its stake in HK Telecom to below 50 percent.
HK Telecom surged to a record high of HK$19.25 on Friday on speculation of an impending deal before drifting slightly to close at HK$19.00.

Analysts said that after the frenzied buying of the past two months, the change in shareholding was already reflected in Telecom's price. They also said the HK$14.25 price at which C&W sold its shares to China Telecom was fair.
"The deal is beneficial to both parties, so of course Cable & Wireless would have to make some concession," said Dharmala Securities' Kwong.
HK Telecom's Cheung said on Friday said the price reflected the shares' average close for the past 30 trading days.
Some analysts have questioned China Telecom's ability to finance the purchase of a large stake in HK Telecom.
But Mansion House Securities's Ng said the company should have no problem funding the US$1.185 billion, or HK$9.17 billion, 5.5 percent stake.
"Quite a lot of banks will be willing to lend the money, especially when you are talking about the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications," he said.
